25708779.trustfund: TF020090-BELGIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF021936-OTF - TUNISIA ODS PHASEOUT PROJECT,BBMPT-BB MONTREAL PROTOCOL

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Demonstration Project for the
            Phase-out of Ozone Depleting Substances

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Demonstration Project
            for the Phase-out of Ozone Depleting Substances in Tunisia
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the lack of any formal evaluation of
            project performance until the Implementation Completion and
            Results Report, or ICR has left inherent weaknesses and
            performance issues undiscovered for too long. In future,
            regular mid-term reviews should be held, and sector units
            should strongly consider the option of a series of
            programmatic or repeater projects to carry out a long
            mandate such as this. Such an approach will allow regular
            opportunities to reassess the project design and objectives
            and will help to ensure that a large gap does not develop
            between the intended purpose of the project and its actual
            activities. This lesson is widely applicable across the Bank
            portfolio, but in most cases regular review is already in
            place and prevents 'mission creep' from reaching
            the very large proportions it reached in the case of this project.

5080217.trustfund: TF021936-OTF - TUNISIA ODS PHASEOUT PROJECT,TF020090-BELGIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Phaseout of Ozone Depleting
            Substances Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Phaseout of Ozone
            Depleting Substances (ODS) Project are to: 1) establish the
            institutional and regulatory framework for decreasing ODS
            uses; and 2) introduce ODS-free technologies to the
            refrigeration, foam and aerosol industries as a first
            demonstration phase in completing an early ODS phaseout
            program. The project consists of two main components
            involving institutional strengthening and technology
            transfer. The technology development component includes the
            following: 1) in the refrigeration sector, introduction of
            hydrofluorocarbon 134a (HFC-134a) as a refrigerant replacing
            chlorofluorocarbon 12 (CFC-12), replacement of CFC-11 as a
            foam-blowing agent by a low CFC and/or non-CFC substance,
            and the introduction of a CFC-recycling and refrigeration
            maintenance program to train refrigeration technicians how
            to recycle CFCs and handle non-ODS refrigerants; 2) flexible
            foam which will demonstrate the replacement of CFC-11 with a
            non-ODS substitute; and 3) an aerosol component which will
            consist of a sectoral study in order to determine the full
            technical and financial needs for technology development.
            Finally, the institutional strengthening component will
            consist of establishing the Ozone Project Implementation
            Unit which will be responsible for execution of the project.
